title-group.article-title: Guaranteed Tuition Policies and State General Appropriations for Higher Education: A Difference-in-Difference Analysis

p.mixed-citation: Because each institution is able to manage its own guaranteed tuition program, there is some vari- ance in program details by campus. Illinois State University voluntarily includes fees in their guarantee (However, we argue that ISUs fee guarantee is very weak since the "University reserves the right to impose new or special fee assessments as it deems necessary" http://studentaccounts.illinoisstate.edu/ downloads/TruthinTuitionProcedures3-28-12.pdf). Western Illinois University includes tuition, fees, and room and board in its guarantee making it the most extensive program in the state. Every institution voluntarily extends a guarantee to nonresident students except for Northern Illinois University and Governors State University. Chicago State University extends its guarantee to six years or 120 hours. Northern Illinois University offers its guaranteed for nine semesters (and does not count summer en- rollment towards this total). Governors State University offers its guarantee for 11 terms.

This time period coincides with a significant recessionary period in the U.S. business cycle. How- ever, prior work shows no significant decreases in state general appropriations for higher education during the period due to the "maintenance of effort provision" and the federal stimulus funds provided through the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) of 2009 (Delaney 2014). Because of ARRA, the behavior of states and institutions is not expected to shift substantially with changes in the business cycle throughout the period.
There does appear to be one state (MN) on an unusual trend in Figure 3, but Illinois (the solid line) appears to be very similar to the general trend for all other states during these years.

The Delta Cost Project has developed a longitudinal version of IPEDS. However, Delta Cost Project data are not used in this work due to the treatment of parent/child campuses in the datasets. In the Delta Cost Project datasets, multi-campus systems are presented as one institution. This is problematic for our study since we are interested in state appropriations for each campus. For example, the University of Illinois—a three campus system in the treatment group of the study—is reported as a single institution in the Delta Cost Project dataset. Hence, we selected IPEDS datasets for use in this study. One challenge in using the IPEDS data as a cross-sectional time series is that not all of the variables used in this analysis were collected for all of the years in our dataset (from 2000-2012). In two cases (with state appropria- tions and gross Pell grants) one single variable was unable to be used and two nearly identical measures were combined in order to create a continuous measure for every year of the dataset. The definition of the variables did not fundamentally change and in both cases one variable was available for the years 2000-2001 and a second variable was available for the years 2002-2012. A detailed listing of the com- bined variable names and descriptions is available in Table 1.
Institutional tuition levels are not included as an institutional control in the model, because tuition and state general appropriations are likely to be endogenous.

This study uses the following IPEDS variables for these restrictions: iclevel, coded as 1 (four or more years); control, coded as 1 (Public); sector, coded as 1 (Public, 4-year or above); cyactive, coded as 1 (Yes); deggrant, coded as 1 (Degree-granting); ugoffer, coded as 1 (undergraduate degree or certificate offering); obereg, to drop institutions coded as 0 (U.S. Service schools); and opeflag, to restrict the data- set to exclude non-Title IV eligible institutions (coded as 5, 6, or 7).

This study uses the 2000 Carnegie classification system (not the 2010 revised system), because it offers a more straightforward classification scheme and was in place for the majority of the years of the dataset.

These institutions are: Clarion University of Pennsylvania-Venango Campus, CUNY Graduate School and University Center, Lincoln University of Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania State University-Penn St Harrisburg, Pennsylvania State University-Main Campus, Rutgers University-Camden, Rutgers University-New Brunswick, Rutgers University-Newark, SUNY Institute of Technology at Utica-Rome, Temple University, Texas A & M University-Texarkana, University of Baltimore, University of Califor- nia-San Francisco, University Of Delaware, University of Houston-Clear Lake, University of Houston- Victoria, University of Maryland-Baltimore, and University of Pittsburgh-Main Campus.

In addition, one-year of observations for four institutions was dropped from the dataset due to likely data errors. Observations that showed an unusually high out-of-state enrollment percent were dropped. In none of the other years of observations did any of these institutions have an out-of-state enrollment value greater than 27% or 1400 students. Hence observations that reported greater than 85% or more than 3000 in a single year out-of-state students were dropped. These included East Central University in 2000, Grand Valley State University in 2001, University of South Florida in 2003, and the University of Washington-Seattle Campus in 2000.
A list of institutions included in the analysis is available from the authors by request.

In order to identify this subset of states, we use the Education Commission of the States (ECS) Postsecondary Governance Structures Database, which is based on McGuinness (1997). Our data come from Tandberg (personal communication, October 21, 2013). Because governance structure changes are rare within the states, we chose a single year, 2004 (the year before the Illinois guaranteed tuition law went into effect), to identify the states with Coordinating/Planning Governing Boards. More in- formation on this measure and the categories used can be found in Table 1. States that are included in this category of Coordinating/Planning Board governance structure are: Alabama, Arkansas, Colorado, Connecticut, Idaho, Illinois, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Minnesota, North Dakota, New Hampshire, Nevada, New York, Ohio, Rhode Island, South Dakota, Tennessee, and Washington.

Based on the 2000 Carnegie classification system Illinois institutions are categorized as follows: Masters Colleges and Universities I = Chicago State University, Eastern Illinois University, Western Il- linois University, Governors State University, Northeastern Illinois University, University of Illinois at Springfield, Southern Illinois University - Edwardsville; Doctoral/Research Universities—Extensive = University of Illinois at Chicago, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Northern Illinois Uni- versity, Southern Illinois University - Carbondale; Doctoral/Research Universities—Intensive = Illinois State University. No Illinois institutions change categories in the dataset during the time period of the analysis and these are the only three types of public four-year institutions operating in Illinois during the time period of this study.

This robustness check excludes institutions from the dataset that independently instituted any type of price guarantee (in-state, out-of-state tuition, or fees) in any year. These nine excluded public institutions are: Missouri Southern State University, Norfolk State University, Northern Arizona Univer- sity, Tarleton State University, University of Colorado at Boulder, University of Kansas, The University of Texas at Dallas, and The University of Texas at El Paso. The IPEDS variables used to implement this restriction are chgltgtd, chg2tgtd, chg3tgtd, chglfgtd, chg2fgtd, and chg3fgtd. Because the guaranteed tuition program in Oklahoma was instituted by a state law, all Oklahoma institutions remain in the dataset.
